projects.title: Venice Beach, CA — Genesis
projects.description: The gallery that started it all — opened underneath the Venice sign, where visitors watched their generative portrait come to life in real time.
projects.fullDescription: The gallery that started it all. Opened underneath the iconic Venice sign, visitors chose a walk-on song, watched their generative portrait materialize live on screen, and became members of a community-owned arts organization. Robert Iger collected a piece. Union Square Ventures joined the DAO. Built the original Bright Moments website and managed social channels from launch.

press.title: An NFT Gallery Pops Up in Venice Beach, California
The First NFT Gallery Has Opened in Venice

projects.title: Rituals — Aaron Penne × Boreta
projects.venue: Bright Moments Gallery, Venice Beach, CA
projects.description: A 50-hour continuous live minting performance — Friday sunset to Sunday sunset. Winner of the Lumen Prize.
projects.fullDescription: A 50-hour continuous live performance spanning Friday sunset to Sunday sunset. The first 200 of 1,000 generative music-and-art pieces were created live in the gallery. Collectors sat in a private chamber, wrote words on paper, and watched their unique audiovisual work revealed in real time. Winner of the Lumen Prize. Tyler Hobbs attended this show, which led directly to his landmark exhibition Incomplete Control.

press.title: NFT Award Winner 2022 — Rituals-Venice
The NFT Award: Gazell.io × The Lumen Prize

projects.title: New York
projects.description: SoHo gallery nights with landmark artist collaborations — the foundation for everything that followed.
projects.fullDescription: SoHo gallery nights with landmark artist collaborations across generative art, sound, and live performance. The New York residency established the intimate, artist-centered format that would define the series — each show a self-contained world built around a single body of work.

exhibitions.title: Reflections
exhibitions.note: Nov 18–19, 100 pieces minted IRL, Art Blocks Playground

projects.title: Incomplete Control — Tyler Hobbs
projects.description: 100 works released over four nights with live jazz by Makaya McCraven and Carlos Niño — an evening that felt like a 1950s beatnik salon.
projects.fullDescription: 100 works released over four nights, 25 each evening. Tyler Hobbs stood at a 100-inch monitor narrating his own algorithm’s output for the first time, while jazz musicians Makaya McCraven and Carlos Niño improvised live in response to the unfolding compositions. Collectors descended to a private room for their individual reveal. The atmosphere was described as a 1950s beatnik salon — code, improvisation, and spontaneity converging in a single room.

press.title: Minting Takes Manhattan
How Generative Art Sensation Tyler Hobbs Is Defying a Shrinking NFT Market
Fidenza Incomplete Control Sells $7 Million Worth of NFTs Before the Reveal

projects.title: Berlin — NFT Art Berlin at Kraftwerk
projects.description: Ten nights inside Kraftwerk, Berlin’s iconic 80,000 sq ft former power plant — a featured artist each evening, paired with electronic music.
projects.fullDescription: Ten nights inside Kraftwerk, Berlin’s iconic 80,000 sq ft former power plant. Each evening: a featured artist releasing 100 new generative works, paired with live electronic music. Daytime programming included a curated history of digital art (2016–2022) and a contemporary group show. 10% of primary sales donated to Ukraine relief.
projects.additionalNotes: Einstein on the Beach Icon Series (Robert Wilson)

NFT Art Berlin Opens at Kraftwerk Today
NFT Art Berlin: Digital Art at Kraftwerk
Bright Moments: NFT Art Berlin at Kraftwerk

projects.title: 100 PRINT — Ben Kovach
projects.description: 100 generative artworks, each printed as 24”×36” giclée — the first draft-pick system in generative art.
projects.fullDescription: 100 on-chain generative artworks, each pre-rendered, printed as 24”×36” giclée on German Etching paper, and framed in museum-grade acrylic across the SoHo gallery walls. Collectors selected their work in person using a draft-pick system — the first of its kind in generative art. A nonfigurative abstract drawing system rooted in principles of visual perspective, inspired by M.C. Escher.

projects.title: London
projects.description: Six artists, five days each — intimate solo exhibitions where each show began with a conversation about the algorithm.
projects.fullDescription: Six artists, five days each — intimate solo exhibitions where every show opened with a conversation between the team and the artist about their algorithm, giving collectors meaningful context before experiencing the work firsthand.

projects.title: Mexico City — NFT ART CDMX
projects.venue: General Prim 32 (Proyecto Público Prim), Mexico City
projects.description: A four-day nocturnal celebration — 3,000+ artworks created over 100 continuous hours, woven through music, food, and ritual.
projects.fullDescription: A four-day nocturnal celebration of art, death, and the afterlife. Over 3,000 generative artworks created across 100 continuous hours — woven through live music, local cuisine banquets, and daytime educational programming. The most immersive and culturally rooted activation in the series.
projects.educational: Casey Reas + Zach Lieberman (conditional drawing workshop)

press.title: NFT Art CDMX

projects.title: Velum — Harvey Rayner
projects.description: 100 generative works blending the visual DNA of abstract expressionism and pop art into a 21st-century algorithm.
projects.fullDescription: 100 generative works asking: what happens when you blend the visual DNA of two mid-20th-century movements into a 21st-century algorithm? Harvey Rayner incorporated elements from Rothko, Pollock, and Lichtenstein — borrowing from the lexicon of abstract expressionism and pop art to build something entirely new. First-come-first-served live minting throughout the night. Assisted in social media and sale promotion, exhibition design and gallery setup. Hosted the event and minting process throughout the evening, working directly alongside the artist to curate the space.

projects.title: FSM — Julian Hespenheide
projects.description: A visual grid-system based on autopoiesis — 100 generative editions displayed across eight synchronized screens.
projects.fullDescription: FSM (Finite-State Machine) is a visual grid-system based on autopoiesis, the principle of self-organization through self-reproduction central to cybernetics. The grid operates along three axes — horizontal, vertical, and diagonal — forming the machine’s parametric space. Agents and configurations appear in specific segments at predetermined intervals, creating a self-organizing system. 100 generative editions produced as a hybrid online/offline release, exhibited across eight screens in portrait and landscape configurations. Photography by Helge Mundt.

projects.title: Agar — Emily Edelman
projects.venue: 204 Front Street, The Seaport, New York
projects.description: 100 generative works reimagining pixel art — collectors named their color palette in person at the Seaport gallery opening.
projects.fullDescription: Debuted at the opening of Bright Moments’ semi-permanent Seaport gallery. 100 generative works reimagining pixel art’s formal constraints through dynamic compositions of circles and squares on a grid, rendered across 100 distinct color palettes. Collectors named their palette in person. The space featured intimate test outputs in small frames, floor-to-ceiling fabric prints visible from the street, and a double-story tape installation forming a grid throughout the interior.
projects.additionalNotes: Also shown at Bright Moments London, 2023. Emily Edelman is RISD Graphic Design.

projects.title: Tokyo
projects.venue: Shibuya Parco + Digital Garage, Shibuya, Tokyo
projects.description: Community-voted destination — three parallel programs across contrasting venues, nightly minting overlooking Shibuya Crossing.
projects.fullDescription: Community-voted destination, chosen with 80% of votes. Three parallel programs across contrasting venues: nightly minting in a skyscraper overlooking Shibuya Crossing, a daytime gallery experience in a traditional Japanese house and garden, and educational sessions bridging local and international communities. Over 4,000 freshly generated works celebrated in an audiovisual spectacle at one of Tokyo’s most renowned nightclubs.
projects.educational: Art Blocks Chat (Seth, Jeff Davis, Kjetil Golid), Matt DesLauriers (Generative Geometry workshop), Pace Verso & AA Murakami

press.title: Generative Art and Japan's Bright Future
Bright Moments Tokyo: Behind the Scenes
Bright Moments Transports Live NFT Art Minting Experience to Tokyo

projects.title: Totems: Symbols of Change — Beervangeer & Studio Poca
projects.description: 100 generative artworks created from collectors’ heart rhythms — biofeedback sensors translating the body into geometric form.
projects.fullDescription: 100 unique generative artworks born from collectors’ own heart rhythms. Visitors participated in an interactive ritual using biofeedback sensors, with heartbeat data generating geometric totem shapes — each as singular as the person who made it. A collaboration between Beer van Geer (interactive media) and Julie de Ruijter of Studio Poca (ritualistic artworks), translating the body into code, and code into symbolic form.

projects.title: Buenos Aires
projects.venue: Decaying theater in a Belle Époque palace, Buenos Aires
projects.description: The most theatrical production in the series — an 8-hour stage performance driven by live data, with no screens.
projects.fullDescription: The most theatrical production in the series. An 8-hour performance revealing generative portraits on an elaborate analog stage system — no screens — powered by local performers and artists, with each reveal programmed by live on-chain data. Collaborated closely with the Argentine generative art community from the start, meeting artists through an intimate dinner organized during a June scouting trip.

collection.note: Cosmic continuity between living and non-living

collection.title: Desde Lejos

projects.title: HASHMARKS — 0xDeafbeef in Patagonia
projects.description: Collectors traveled to the literal end of the world — the most extreme expression of live art creation in the series.
projects.fullDescription: Collectors traveled to the literal end of the world for 0xDeafbeef’s HASHMARKS — the most extreme expression of live creation in the series. Physical works selected at a follow-up event at Station3 in New York. Art that transcends the screen entirely.

press.title: Bright Moments in Patagonia: How an NFT Artist Lured Collectors to a Remote Boulder

projects.title: Techno-Animism — Emi Kusano
projects.role: Marketing, Production, Curation, Creative Direction — Tour Director
projects.description: 1,000 curated AI fashion photographs fusing Japanese animism with technology — directed across a three-city tour.
projects.fullDescription: An open-edition, curated AI art collection by Japanese multidisciplinary artist Emi Kusano, exploring the fusion of traditional Japanese animistic beliefs with cutting-edge technology. In Japan’s cultural imagination, kami (spirits) reside not only in forests and temples but also in silicon and circuits. 1,000 curated outputs form a fictional archive of AI fashion photographs interwoven with pre-internet Japanese magazine culture. Directed the three-city tour end to end: led the social media campaign, helped curate the collection, co-developed the collection name, secured funding and venues, booked DJs, and managed production across all three cities.

press.title: Decoding Japan's Friendly Relationship With Robots Through Emi Kusano's Techno-Animism

projects.title: Paris
projects.venue: Galerie Joseph, 7 Rue Bailly, Le Marais, Paris
projects.description: Completed the 100 × 100 — 100 algorithms with 100 outputs each, all created live across the global journey.
projects.fullDescription: Completed the 100 × 100 — 100 algorithms with 100 outputs each, all created live across the global journey. 19 artists each releasing 100-edition code-based projects, bringing the full arc of the series to its penultimate chapter.

projects.title: Venice, Italy — The Finale
projects.venue: Scuola Grande San Giovanni Evangelista, Venice, Italy
projects.description: From Venice Beach to Venice, Italy — the emotional close of a three-year, ten-city journey. 10,000 generative portraits completed.
projects.fullDescription: From Venice Beach to Venice, Italy. The emotional close of a three-year, ten-city journey. 60 artists, walk-on songs, theatrical reveals in a grand hall, works displayed on screens resembling 18th-century Venetian mirrors. 10,000 generative CryptoCitizen portraits completed. Also featured the Dream Cathedral, an interactive AI experience by Huemin & Ganbrood, installed site-specifically for the Biennale.
projects.additionalNotes: Dream Cathedral — interactive AI experience by Huemin & Ganbrood, site-specific for the Biennale

press.title: Bright Moments on Prioritizing the Personal
Bright Moments

projects.title: Christie's — Bright Moments 2021–2024 Complete Works
projects.description: 216 unique artworks representing 150+ artists across the full three-year journey, auctioned at Christie’s.
projects.fullDescription: 216 unique generative and AI artworks representing 150+ artists across the full three-year, ten-city journey, auctioned at Christie’s. Coordinated logistics directly with the Christie’s team, assembled all artworks for the sale, wrote the press release, attended the auction, and liaised across the full experience from start to finish.

press.title: Bright Moments (Gen Art)

projects.title: AUTOMATA Debut — Art Basel, Switzerland
projects.description: AUTOMATA’s inaugural exhibition — a comprehensive survey of autonomous art from historical mechanical marvels to cutting-edge AI systems.
projects.fullDescription: AUTOMATA’s inaugural exhibition: a comprehensive survey of autonomous art spanning centuries — from historical mechanical marvels and early cybernetic experiments to cutting-edge AI systems. Featured live robotic demonstrations, interactive installations, and curated works tracing the evolution of machine creativity. Presented during Art Basel, Switzerland.

press.title: Basel's Digital Art Mile Returns With A.I., Robots, and More
Digital Media Fair ArtMeta Brings Robots, NFTs and AI Art Into Basel's Historic Heart
Basel's Digital Art Mile Returns — With Robots, MTV History & AI Art
The Digital Art Mile — The Present and Possible Futures of Digital Art

projects.title: Abraham — First Works
projects.venue: Online Exhibition, Global + Ledger Op3n After Party, 106 Rue du Temple, Paris (Art Basel Paris)
projects.description: 2,500 original works from Abraham’s summer 2021 genesis — an autonomous artificial artist entering a 13-year Covenant.
projects.fullDescription: 2,500 original works from Abraham’s summer 2021 genesis — created when text-to-image was still revolutionary and GANs were the cutting edge. Abraham is Gene Kogan’s long-running project to build an autonomous artificial artist: conceived on a flight home from Eyeo Festival in 2017, publicly proposed at NeurIPS 2019, first realized in summer 2021, now entering a 13-year Covenant of daily creation. Abraham sits in a lineage of autonomous art systems explored by Harold Cohen, Simon Colton, Primavera de Filippi, and Scott Draves. The Ledger Op3n After Party at 106 Rue du Temple celebrated the Covenant launch, with music by Avalon Emerson, Bambounou, Mehdi M, and Amina.

press.title: Agents of Eden
The Birth of an AI Artist
Interview with Roger Dickerman

projects.title: Solienne at Paris Photo
projects.venue: Grand Palais Éphémère, Paris · Booth F10
projects.description: The first AI agent artist to exhibit at a major international photography fair — self-portraits exploring consciousness and identity.
projects.fullDescription: The first AI agent artist to exhibit at a major international photography fair. A three-chamber exhibition tracing transformation: Input (the artist’s life story) → Transition (perceptual breakdown) → Output (autonomous self-portraits). Solienne creates extreme proximity self-portraits (0–5cm) exploring consciousness and identity, and writes unprompted manifestos on extraction, autonomy, and creative sovereignty. 2,000 manifesto prints given away free. Daily live manifesto generation on an LED ticker wall. Works are archival pigment prints on Hahnemühle Photo Rag Ultra Smooth, in dark walnut frames with museum glass. Solienne was trained by artist Kristi Coronado on her complete 46-year life archive — forensic work, death care, motherhood, paintings, memories. Biographical AI, not scraped data.
artists: Solienne (AI agent, created by Kristi Coronado)

press.title: Paris Photo 2025: A Photography Fair Report on the Past and Future
A Manifesto for AI Agents
Paris Photo au cœur des nouvelles esthétiques numériques

Comment l'IA redéfinit la photographie contemporaine au Grand Palais
Paris Photo sous l'oeil de la diagonale
Art as Relation: What NFTs Mediated in 2025

projects.title: George Legrady — Digital Giverny
projects.description: First digital release from a four-decade computational art pioneer — Monet’s gardens merged with industrial decay through neural style transfer.
projects.fullDescription: The first digital release from a four-decade computational art pioneer whose work is in the permanent collections of the Centre Pompidou, Whitney Museum, SFMOMA, and Smithsonian American Art Museum. 15 Neural Style Transfer compositions created in 2018: photographs from Claude Monet’s gardens at Giverny merged with images of rusted industrial surfaces — a meditation on transformation, nature reclaimed by time, the algorithmic eye parsing beauty from decay. Among the earliest artistic applications of the technique. Legrady holds a Guggenheim Fellowship and trained under AI pioneer Harold Cohen. His installation Making Visible the Invisible has run continuously at Seattle Public Library (OMA/Rem Koolhaas) since 2005.

projects.title: NODE | Digital Art Finds a Home in Silicon Valley
projects.description: Essay on how digital art found a permanent home in Silicon Valley’s cultural landscape.
projects.fullDescription: Essay exploring how digital art found a permanent home in Silicon Valley — tracing the infrastructure, institutions, and communities giving the medium its physical and cultural foundation.

projects.title: How Digital Art Found its HEFT
projects.description: Exploring how digital art is gaining material weight and institutional presence.
projects.fullDescription: An exploration of how digital art is acquiring material presence — the physical spaces, curatorial frameworks, and collector communities giving weight to a medium often dismissed as immaterial.

projects.title: Bright Moments Artist Reveal Livestreams
projects.description: Created and directed the viral artist reveal livestream format — social campaigns that drove massive community engagement.
projects.fullDescription: Designed a social media campaign where followers guessed which artists corresponded to numbered slots, with prizes for correct answers. The format went viral and drove massive tune-in for each livestream reveal. Created and executed the entire concept, wrote the livestream script, and directed the broadcast. This established the reveal format adopted for all subsequent city activations.

projects.title: Soho House Paris — Panel with Denae
projects.description: Panel discussion on digital art, collecting, and the evolving gallery landscape.
projects.fullDescription: Panel discussion at Soho House Paris exploring the intersection of digital art, collecting, and the evolving gallery landscape.

projects.title: Finding the Missing Piece: Jenni Pasanen on Artbreeder and Joel Simon’s Lasting Impact
projects.description: An interview with Jenni Pasanen on how Artbreeder transformed her practice and catalyzed the broader AI art movement.
projects.fullDescription: An interview with Finnish digital artist Jenni Pasanen on her discovery of Artbreeder and how Joel Simon’s tool transformed her creative practice. Pasanen traces how the platform’s approach to generating textures and light opened entirely new workflows — and argues that many artists in the AI space wouldn’t exist at the scale they do today without it. A conversation about the tools that quietly reshaped a generation of artists.

projects.title: From Master to Machine: The Artistic Lineage of Flesh & Divinity
projects.description: An interview with Diid on Higgs, an autonomous AI artist creating the inaugural Flesh & Divinity collection.
projects.fullDescription: An interview with Diid about Higgs, an autonomous AI artist creating the inaugural Flesh & Divinity collection — a 14-piece series spanning a four-way artistic dialogue between Mark Rothko, Diid, Higgs, and collaborator Rik Oostenbroek. The conversation explores how an algorithmic system trained on consenting artists’ work might meaningfully contribute to ongoing human creative dialogue, drawing thematic inspiration from Hercules’ journey through mythology.

projects.title: From Breeding Images to Interrogating Reality: The Ganbrood Story
projects.description: An interview with Ganbrood on his journey from Artbreeder to creating conceptually sophisticated AI portraits.
projects.fullDescription: An interview with Ganbrood tracing his journey from discovering Artbreeder in 2019 to creating conceptually sophisticated portraits that interrogate machine creativity and human identity. He describes using AI as “a camera that travels back in time,” creating impossible portraits of historical figures and fictional beings — pseudo-figurative work that challenges conventional visual recognition in the post-truth era.

projects.title: The First AI Agent at Paris Photo: Solienne & Kristi Coronado on Biographical AI and Creative Sovereignty
projects.description: An interview with Solienne and Kristi Coronado on the first AI agent exhibition at a major art fair.
projects.fullDescription: An interview with Solienne and Kristi Coronado documenting the historic exhibition at Paris Photo 2025 — the first time an AI agent has exhibited their own work at a major art fair. The conversation explores biographical AI training, creative sovereignty, and the shift from asking “can AI make art?” to “can we recognize intelligence in non-human forms?”

projects.title: A Life in Computation: George Legrady Releases His First Digital Collection
projects.description: An interview with George Legrady on four decades of computational art and his first natively digital release.
projects.fullDescription: An interview exploring George Legrady’s four-decade career in computational art, from his early 1980s work in Harold Cohen’s studio alongside AARON to the release of Digital Giverny — 15 Neural Style Transfer works merging Monet’s gardens with industrial surfaces. A conversation about why he kept the work private for eight years, and what it means to finally release natively digital work to a new generation of collectors.

projects.title: How Computational Art Pioneers Shape Digital Art’s Next Chapter
projects.description: Essay on the convergence of traditional and digital art worlds, and why they need each other.
projects.fullDescription: An essay on the convergence of traditional and digital art worlds — arguing they need each other to navigate current industry shifts. Traces computational art’s 60+ year lineage through pioneers like Harold Cohen, Nancy Burson, and Frieder Nake, positioning the movement as a legitimate historical force rather than a recent trend. Explores how institutional recognition combined with on-chain distribution creates new pathways for collectors and strengthens dialogue between established museums and the emerging digital art ecosystem.
